title: Campaign 2012 turns into a nasty schoolyard brawl
content:
The Obama-Romney race is marked by an increasingly vicious tone . | AP Photos New high ( or low ) in campaign snark
President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney opine about wanting a high-minded campaign — but the race the two men are actually running is marked by an increasingly personal and vicious tone that may well define the 2012 presidential election .
Neither side is proud of what ’ s happened . But neither side is willing to give first . And neither is able to discuss the big issues of the campaign , from Romney ’ s background at Bain Capital to economic policy , without resorting to a stick-in-your-eye back-and-forth .
“ There is an element here of ‘ I know you are , but what am I ’ to this charge , ” White House press secretary Jay Carney said last week , firing back at a question about Romney calling the president the “ outsourcer in chief ” — a response to Obama calling the Republican candidate an “ outsourcing pioneer . ”
On Monday , Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz made the toddler campaign explicit , saying on MSNBC that Romney and his staff “ need to put their big boy and big girl pants on and defend his record . ”
The decline began as soon as Romney clinched the nomination . The Republican candidate ’ s staffers , annoyed they weren ’ t getting the respect they felt they deserved from Obama ’ s staffers , sent a bus honking at those lined up to enter the president ’ s rallies and dispatched bubble-blowing hecklers to an Obama press conference held in Boston , Romney ’ s backyard . Small-bore as it was , the stunts got under the skin of Obama ’ s details and protocol-obsessed campaign , and they couldn ’ t let go . Before long , they dispatched former Pennsylvania Gov . Ed Rendell to appear at a Romney stop at a Wawa convenience store . And they made a show of ordering cookies from a bakery Romney had slighted .
Meanwhile , Obama has mocked Romney ’ s off-key patriotic singing in TV ads , and the Romney campaign has responded with an ad making light of the president ’ s Al Green impression . Romney speaks from the stump about “ Candidate Obama. ” The president refers to “ Mister Romney . ”
It ’ s the kind of behavior few people outside the campaigns ’ headquarters or the respective press buses have heard about , much less care about — but for the staffers and the candidates themselves , that tone has increasingly infected how they relate to each other and the entire tone of the debate .
“ The surprise here is we live in serious times with huge issues hanging over us , and the country is working desperately for a solution , ” said David Gergen , veteran of four administrations . “ And to wake up and see these antics does discourage people . It dampens people ’ s confidence that we ’ ll be able to have someone who can solve problems when this is over . I don ’ t understand it ; I don ’ t understand why [ campaigns ] decide this is funny . ”
The low-level tit-for-tats represent the latest derivation of the negative campaign , forever a staple of American politics . But never before the Twitter era have two camps fought so quickly for so little .
Both sides , of course , claim they would rather be addressing more important issues , but instead , they ’ ve been trading insults and demands for apologies , defending their own tactics and incessantly mocking each other for insisting on holding to standards .
CORRECTION : Corrected by : Naira Ruiz @ 07/17/2012 11:55 AM CORRECTION : An earlier version of this story incorrectly described the Obama campaign ’ s involvement in dispatching protesters to a Romney campaign stop .
